docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Deborah Frank and Dr. Alan Meyers, hospital pediatricians, work with children who are undernourished and, as a direct result, are not growing. The only treatment, they say, is nutritious food, a medical necessity that many families at the hospital, Boston Medical Center, cannot afford and that insurance companies do not cover.

headline.main: Hospital Prescribes Food to Aid Children's Growth

docs.abstract: Number of departments at Boston Medical Center start food pantries after finding that undernourished children are not growing as they should; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. Deborah Frank and Dr. Alan Meyers, hospital pediatricians, work with children who are undernourished and, as a direct result, are not growing.    The only treatment, they say, is nutritious food, a medical necessity that many families at the...

docs.lead_paragraph: In searching for a suitable camp for her 11-year-old daughter, Linda Friedman Schmidt of Franklin Lakes, N.J., interviewed at least a dozen camp directors. Among her questions was one that parents rarely ask: is milk served at every meal? The answer each time was ''only at breakfast.''

headline.main: Parents' Rite of Passage: Shopping for a Camp

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column offer guidelines for parents in choosing summer camp for a child; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: In searching for a suitable camp for her 11-year-old daughter, Linda Friedman Schmidt of Franklin Lakes, N.J., interviewed at least a dozen camp directors.    Among her questions was one that parents rarely ask: is milk served at every meal? The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Computer images show the progressive damage of Alzheimer's disease in the human brain. The images are derived from M.R.I. scans of 12 patients, made over two years. Researchers used computers to synthesize the data, creating one generalized view of the diseases progress. The sequence shows that areas involved with memory were damaged first, then structures involved with emotion and control of behavior.

headline.main: Images Map the Destructive Path of Alzheimer's Through the Brain

docs.abstract: Images derived from MRI scans show progressive damage of Alzheimer's disease in human brain (S)
docs.snippet: Computer images show the progressive damage of Alzheimer's disease in the human brain. The images are derived from M.R.I. scans of 12 patients, made over two years. Researchers used computers to synthesize the data, creating one generalized view of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Studies have suggested that people who have a lot of anger may be at higher risk for cardiovascular disease, but a new report finds that the relationship may not be so clear. For men who express some of that anger, the researchers say, the risks may be lower.

headline.main: Blow a Gasket, for Your Heart

docs.abstract: Researchers find that men who harbor anger may reduce threat of cardiovascular disease by expressing some of that anger; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Drivers who use hands-free cellphones thinking that they are safer than hand-held ones are still more prone to accidents than other drivers, a new study reports. The new study, which appears in the March issue of The Journal of Experimental Psychology: Applied, finds that hands-free phones do not address the problem of what researchers called ''inattention blindness.''

headline.main: Cellphone Peril, Hands On or Off

docs.abstract: Study finds that drivers who use hands-free cellphones thinking they are safer than hand-held ones are still more prone to accidents than other drivers (S)
docs.snippet: Drivers who use hands-free cellphones thinking that they are safer than hand-held ones are still more prone to accidents than other drivers, a new study reports.    The new study, which appears in the March issue of The Journal of Experimental...

docs.lead_paragraph: Smallpox vaccination is off to a slow start in the United States, as the argument among doctors over its pros and cons is escalating. To some extent, this hubbub is simply the unhappy reaction of people accustomed to operating off carefully calculated risk-benefit ratios being forced into decisions in a time when such ratios cannot easily be calculated.

headline.main: In Times of Turmoil, Clarion Call for Doctors Often Goes Unanswered

docs.abstract: Smallpox vaccination is off to slow start in United States, as argument among doctors over its pros and cons escalates; doctors accustomed to operating off carefully calculated risk-benefit ratios are being forced into decisions at time when such ratios cannot easily be calculated; desperately want to know true risk of weaponized smallpox, health risks of vaccination for themselves, risks for patients, and risk of other consquences like litigation for untoward vaccine effects; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When James Busby, a Brooklyn music teacher, was battling Kaposi's sarcoma, an AIDS-related cancer, his doctor prescribed some blood-building drugs to help him deal with the side effects of chemotherapy. The drugs allowed Mr. Busby to regain much of his strength. But, he said, they cost about half of his annual income. Mr. Busby eventually got some of his medical costs back -- from the Internal Revenue Service.

headline.main: At Tax Time, Health Care Costs May Be a Factor

docs.abstract: Tax deductions for health and dental costs are becoming more popular as Americans spend more out of pocket for health care (M)
docs.snippet: When James Busby, a Brooklyn music teacher, was battling Kaposi's sarcoma, an AIDS-related cancer, his doctor prescribed some blood-building drugs to help him deal with the side effects of chemotherapy. The drugs allowed Mr. Busby to regain much of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Older scuba divers who are wondering whether it is time to hang up their flippers can take heart: as long as they are in good general condition, a new study reports, there is no reason to give up the activity. Researchers writing in The Journal of Applied Physiology had theorized that because people lost lung function as they aged, older divers might be prone to retaining too much carbon dioxide under the water. The condition can lead to disorientation and even unconsciousness.
docs.abstract: New study finds there is no reason for older scuba divers to give up their diving as long as they are in good general condition (S)
docs.snippet: Older scuba divers who are wondering whether it is time to hang up their flippers can take heart: as long as they are in good general condition, a new study reports, there is no reason to give up the activity.    Researchers writing in The Journal of...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Penn State opened for a new term in January, about 300 students were turned away from their dormitories because they had not complied with a new law requiring students to be vaccinated for meningococcal disease or sign a waiver opting out. Last year, Pennsylvania joined 13 other states that have passed laws concerning the immunization of college students against the disease, a deadly disorder that strikes mostly infants and college students.

headline.main: Rare but Deadly Ailment Catches College Freshmen Unprepared

docs.abstract: Meningococcal disease strikes mostly infants and college students, but some state legislators and college administrators are reluctant to require vaccination of students against deadly disease because it does not provide complete protection and because disease is rare to begin with; proponents of vaccine say it is needed because meningococcal disease can be so devastating; 14 states have passed laws concerning immunization of college students; photos; map (M)
docs.snippet: When Penn State opened for a new term in January, about 300 students were turned away from their dormitories because they had not complied with a new law requiring students to be vaccinated for meningococcal disease or sign a waiver opting out.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Like many of her friends in Miami, Ana Alvarado was starting to feel older, and the deepening wrinkles on her face and forehead only made her feel worse. She wanted to get rid of them forever, but her doctor said that was impossible; everything on the market, including Botox and peels, was temporary. Then, the doctor suggested that she could be a test patient for Artecoll, a wrinkle remover like Botox, with a crucial difference in this case. It was permanent.

headline.main: When Facial Wrinkles Are Ironed Away for Good

docs.abstract: Artecoll, wrinkle filler that permanently removes wrinkles, has gone through five years of clinical trials in United States and it is scheduled to go before FDA for final approval; Artecoll is already on market throughout Europe, Canada and Mexico; Canadian dermatologist notes that permanence can for double-edge sword, for if something goes wrong with Artecoll, damage cannot easily be repaired (M)
